Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, pursuant to sections 8, 43* and 79.7** of the Fisheries Act, is pleased hereby to repeal the British Columbia Sport Fishing Regulations, made by Order in Council P.C. 1982-1920 of June 23, 1982***, and to make the annexed Regulations respecting sport fishing in the Canadian fisheries waters of the Pacific Ocean and of the Province of British Columbia in substitution therefor, effective April 1, 1996.

Footnote.Text: SOR/82-645, 1982 Canada Gazette Part II, p. 2305

Subsection.Text: The definitions in this subsection apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Fisheries Act. (Loi)
angling means fishing with a hook and line, with or without a rod. It does not include fishing with a set line. (pêche à la ligne)
Area has the same meaning as in section 1 of the Pacific Fishery Management Area Regulations, 2007. (secteur)
artificial fly means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in non-tidal waters, a single-pointed hook that is dressed only with fur, feathers, hair, textiles, tinsel, wire or any combination of those materials and to which no external weight or external attracting device is attached; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in tidal waters, a hook, or two hooks tied in tandem, dressed only with fur, feathers, hair, textiles, tinsel, wire or any combination of those materials. (mouche artificielle)

Definition.Text: day means a calendar day. (jour ou journée)
fin fish means all fish other than crustaceans, echinoderms, molluscs, shellfish and marine mammals. (poisson à nageoires)
fly fishing means angling with a line to which only an artificial fly is attached. (pêche à la mouche)
foul hook means to hook a fish in any part of its body other than the mouth. (casaquer)
gill net has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Pacific Fishery Regulations, 1993. (filet maillant)
hatchery trout means a trout of any kind that has a healed scar in place of the adipose fin. (truite d’élevage)
hatchery chinook salmon means a chinook salmon that has a healed scar in place of the adipose, pelvic or pectoral fin, or in place of a maxillary. (saumon quinnat d’élevage)
hatchery coho salmon means a coho salmon that has a healed scar in place of the adipose, pelvic or pectoral fin, or in place of a maxillary. (saumon coho d’élevage)
kokanee means a land-locked sockeye salmon. (kokani)
management unit or M.U. means an area designated as a management unit in section 2 of the Management Unit Regulation made pursuant to the Province’s Wildlife Act. (zone d’aménagement ou Z.A.)
mesh size has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Pacific Fishery Regulations, 1993. (maillage)
natural bait means any foodstuff or natural substance other than wood, cotton, wool, hair, fur or feathers. It does not include fin fish other than roe. (appât naturel)
non-tidal waters eans the waters of the Province other than tidal waters. (eaux sans marée)
overall length with respect to a fish, means the distance measured from the tip of the nose to the fork of the tail or, where there is no fork, to the tip of the tail. (longueur totale)
Province means the Province of British Columbia. (province)
Region means a region as described in section 3 of the Hunting Regulation made pursuant to the Province’s Wildlife Act. (Région)
ring net has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Pacific Fishery Regulations, 1993. (bolinche)
salmon means a chinook salmon, a chum salmon, a coho salmon, a pink salmon or a sockeye salmon other than a kokanee. (saumon)
set line means a fishing line that is left unattended in the water. (ligne fixe)
spear fishing means fishing with a spear or an arrow that is propelled by a spring, an elastic band, compressed air or a bow or by hand. (pêche au harpon)
sport fishing means fishing for recreational purposes. (pêche sportive)
steelhead, in waters where anadromous rainbow trout are found, means a rainbow trout that is greater than 50 cm in overall length. (truite arc-en-ciel anadrome)
stream means a watercourse formed by the perennial or intermittent flow of water between continuous, definable banks and includes a river. (ruisseau)
Subarea has the same meaning as in section 1 of the Pacific Fishery Management Area Regulations, 2007. (sous-secteur)
surfline has the same meaning as in section 1 of the Pacific Fishery Management Area Regulations, 2007. (ligne de démarcation)
tidal portion of the Fraser River means the following Subareas or portions of Subareas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Subarea 29-11 and Subareas 29-13 to 29-17;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the portion of Subarea 29-9 bounded on the west by a line from a fishing boundary sign near the entrance to Canoe Passage, thence to a fishing boundary sign on Westham Island, thence following the westerly shoreline of Westham Island and Reifel Island to Pelly Point on Reifel Island, thence to Garry Point on Lulu Island; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the portion of Subarea 29-12 bounded on the west by a line from the most southwesterly point of Sea Island, thence following the westerly shoreline of that island to the Iona Island Road Causeway, thence following that causeway and continuing in a straight line in a northerly direction to a fishing boundary sign on the north shore of Iona Island, thence in a straight line in a northerly direction to a fishing boundary sign on the mainland. (partie à marée du fleuve Fraser)

Definition.Text: tidal waters means the waters of the Areas set out in Schedule 2 to the Pacific Fishery Management Area Regulations, 2007. (eaux à marée)
trout means brook trout, brown trout, cutthroat trout, Dolly Varden, lake trout, rainbow trout or steelhead. (truite)
wild chinook salmon means a chinook salmon that is not a hatchery chinook salmon. (saumon quinnat sauvage)
wild coho salmon means a coho salmon that is not a hatchery coho salmon. (saumon coho sauvage)
wild trout means a trout that is not a hatchery trout. (truite sauvage)
year means a period beginning on April 1 and ending on March 31. (année)

Subsection.Text: A reference in these Regulations to a species of fish by its common name as set out in column I of an item of Schedule I shall be construed as a reference to the species of fish whose scientific name is set out in column II of that item.
A reference in these Regulations to a measurement of mesh size, depth, length or any other dimension of a net shall be construed as a reference to a measurement taken when the net is wet.
These Regulations apply in respect of sport fishing in the Canadian fisheries waters of the Pacific Ocean and of the Province.
These Regulations do not apply in respect of fishing in waters to which the National Parks of Canada Fishing Regulations apply.
These Regulations do not apply in respect of fishing in the Chilkoot Trail National Historic Site.
These Regulations do not apply to fishing and related activities carried out under the authority of a licence issued under the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations.

Section.Text: Subject to these Regulations, no person shall molest or injure fish.
No person shall fish for, or catch and retain, any species of fish set out in the table to this section.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall angle with more than one fishing line

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in any lake or stream; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for white sturgeon.

Subsection.Text: A person who is alone in a boat may angle with two fishing lines in a lake.

Section.Text: No person shall angle with a fishing line to which is attached a weight that is greater than one kilogram.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4), no person shall angle with a fishing line to which more than one hook, artificial lure or artificial fly is attached.
A person may angle in the tidal portion of the Fraser River with two hooks, artificial lures or artificial flies, attached to a fishing line.
Subject to subsection (4), a person may angle in tidal waters with any number of hooks attached to a fishing line if the hooks are used in combination to hold a single piece of bait.
A person who is angling in tidal waters for herring, northern anchovy, Pacific sand lance or squid may use any number of hooks on a fishing line.

Section.Text: No person shall fish with a dip net unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is hung on a frame that measures no more than 90 cm in its greatest dimension;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the frame is attached to a handle; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the bottom of the dip net is closed to form a bag that is no longer than 1.5 times the greatest dimension of the frame.

Subsection.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: use a light in any manner to attract fish, unless the light is submerged and attached to a fishing line within 1 m of the fish hook;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: catch or attempt to catch fish with snares; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: wilfully foul hook or attempt to foul hook any fish other than herring, northern anchovy, Pacific sand lance and squid.

Subsection.Text: No person who accidentally foul hooks a fish in a lake or stream shall retain the fish.

Section.Text: No person shall angle from a vessel that is equipped with a motor in the waters set out in column I of an item of Schedule II situated in the M.U. set out in column II of that item during the period set out in column III of that item.

No person shall angle from a vessel in the waters set out in column I of an item of Schedule III situated in the M.U. set out in column II of that item during the period set out in column III of that item.

Subsection.Text: No person shall possess more fish of a species, other than halibut, except at the person’s ordinary residence, than twice the daily quota for fish of that species prescribed by these Regulations.
No person shall possess more than 3 halibut, except at the person’s ordinary residence.

Section.Text: No person on board a vessel shall possess any halibut taken by sport fishing if there are any other fish on board the vessel that are destined for sale, trade or barter.
This Part applies to fishing in tidal waters.
The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: conservation stamp means a stamp issued under section 17 that bears the words “salmon conservation/conservation du saumon” and the year for which the conservation stamp is valid. (timbre de conservation)
licence means a tidal waters sport fishing licence issued under section 17. (permis)

Section.Text: The Minister may issue a licence or a conservation stamp to a person on request and on payment of the applicable fee set out in the table to this section.

row.entry: Licence, resident under 16 years of age, annual
Licence, resident 16 to 64 years of age, annual
Licence, resident 65 years of age or older, annual
Licence, non-resident under 16 years of age, annual
Licence, non-resident 16 years of age or older, annual

Provision.Label: NOTE:
Provision.Text: For the purposes of this table, resident means a person who normally resides in Canada.

Subsection.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fish unless the person holds a licence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: catch and retain salmon unless the person holds a licence to which is permanently affixed a conservation stamp that is valid for the same year as the licence.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(a) does not apply on the third Sunday in June or the Friday or Saturday immediately preceding that day.

Section.Text: No person shall harvest herring spawn on kelp other than under the authority of a licence issued under the Fishery (General) Regulations, the Pacific Fishery Regulations, 1993 or the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations.
No person shall hold more than one licence.
Where a licence holder catches and retains a lingcod or a chinook salmon, the licence holder shall immediately record the catch in ink on the licence.

Heading.Label: PART II
Heading.TitleText: Fishing for Fin Fish Other than Salmon in Tidal Waters

Section.Text: This Part applies to fishing for fin fish other than salmon in tidal waters.

Subsection.Text: No person shall fish for fish of a species set out in column I of an item of Schedule IV, in any Subarea, with a type of gear or by a method set out in column III of that item during the close time set out in column IV of that item.
The close time set out in column IV of item 21 of Schedule IV is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of fish set out in column I.
No person shall catch and retain in a day more fish of a species set out in column I of Schedule IV, in any Subarea, than the daily quota set out in column II.
The quota set out in column II of item 21 of Schedule IV is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of fish set out in column I.

Section.Text: No person shall, in a day, catch and retain more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: four wild trout and hatchery trout, in the aggregate, in any Subarea;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: four wild trout and hatchery trout, in the aggregate; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: eight rockfish.

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a year more than 10 lingcod in the aggregate from Areas 11 to 19, 28 and 29 and Subareas 20-5 to 20-7.
No person shall catch and retain more than one white sturgeon in a year.
No person shall catch and retain in any Subarea

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a white sturgeon that measures less than 100 cm or more than 150 cm in overall length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a wild trout that measures less than 30 cm in overall length;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a hatchery trout that measures less than 30 cm in overall length; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a lingcod that measures less than 65 cm in overall length or that measures, with the head off, less than 53 cm in length when measured along the shortest length of the body to the tip of the tail.

Section.Text: No person shall fish for fish of a species set out in column I of an item of Schedule IV other than with a type of gear or by a method set out in column III of that item.
No person shall fish for eulachon or smelt with a gill net

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that exceeds 7.5 m in length; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that has a mesh size of less than 25 mm or more than 50 mm.

Section.Text: No person shall fish for eulachon or smelt with more than one net at a time.

Heading.Label: PART III
Heading.TitleText: Fishing for Crustaceans, Echinoderms, Molluscs and Shellfish in Tidal Waters

Section.Text: This Part applies to fishing for crustaceans, echinoderms, molluscs and shellfish in tidal waters.

Subsection.Text: No person shall fish for fish of a species set out in column I of an item of Schedule V, in any Subarea, with a type of gear or by a method set out in column III of that item during the close time set out in column IV of that item.
The close time set out in column IV of subitem 3(6) of Schedule V is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of crab set out in column I.
The close time set out in column IV of item 19 of Schedule V is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of fish set out in column I.
No person shall catch and retain in a day more fish of a species set out in column I of Schedule V, in any Subarea, than the daily quota set out in column II.
The quota set out in column II of subitem 3(6) of Schedule V is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of crab referred to in column I.
The quota set out in column II of item 19 of Schedule V is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of fish referred to in column I.

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a day more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 75 clams;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: four Dungeness crab and red rock crab, in the aggregate, in all of Areas 11 to 20, 28 and 29;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: six Dungeness crab, red rock crab and king crab, in the aggregate, in all of Areas 1 to 10 and 21 to 27 or in any Subarea outside the surfline;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: 75 mussels; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: six purple-hinged rock scallops and weather-vane scallops in the aggregate.

Subsection.Text: No person shall catch and retain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an abalone that measures less than 100 mm in a straight line through the greatest breadth of the shell;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a Dungeness crab that measures less than 165 mm in a straight line through the greatest breadth of the carapace; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a red rock crab that measures less than 115 mm in a straight line through the greatest breadth of the carapace

Subsection.Text: No person shall remove an abalone from its resting place without first ensuring that it is of a size greater than that described in paragraph (1)(a).

Section.Text: No person shall fish for fish of a species set out in column I of an item of Schedule V other than with a type of gear or by a method set out in column III of that item.

Subsection.Text: No person shall fish for crab with more than two ring nets, dip nets and crab traps in the aggregate.
No person shall fish for crab with a ring net or crab trap unless a tag, float or buoy that bears the operator’s name is attached to the net or trap.
Despite subsection (2), if two crab traps are attached to one ground-line, it is sufficient to attach a tag, float or buoy that bears the operator’s name to one end of the ground-line.
No person shall fish for shrimp with more than four shrimp traps.
No person shall fish for shrimp with a shrimp trap unless a tag, float or buoy that bears the operator’s name is attached to the trap.
Despite subsection (2), if two traps are attached to one ground-line, it is sufficient to attach a tag, float or buoy that bears the operator’s name to one end of the ground-line.
For greater certainty, if more than two traps are attached to one ground-line, paragraph 27(6)(b) of the Fishery (General) Regulations applies.
No person shall fish for octopus with an octopus trap unless a tag, float or buoy that bears the operator’s name is attached to the trap.
Despite subsection (1), if two traps are attached to one ground-line, it is sufficient to attach a tag, float or buoy that bears the operator’s name to one end of the ground-line.
For greater certainty, if more than two traps are attached to one ground-line, paragraph 27(6)(b) of the Fishery (General) Regulations applies.

Section.Text: No person shall fish with a crab trap unless the trap has a section in the top or in a sidewall that has been laced, sewn or otherwise secured by a single length of untreated cotton twine no greater than grade No. 120, which, on deterioration or parting, produces a rectangular opening with a minimum size of 7 cm × 20 cm or a square opening with a minimum size of 11 cm × 11 cm.

No person shall set, operate or leave unattended in the water any ring net or any crab, shrimp or octopus trap unless the tag, float or buoy attached to the ring net or trap bears the operator’s name.

Heading.Label: PART IV
Heading.TitleText: Fishing for Salmon in Tidal and Non-Tidal Waters

Section.Text: This Part applies to fishing for salmon in tidal and non-tidal waters.
No person shall fish for salmon of a species set out in column I of an item of Schedule VI, in any Subarea, lake or stream, during the close time set out in column V of that item.

No person shall catch and retain in a day more salmon of a species set out in column I of an item of Schedule VI, of an overall length set out in column III of that item, in any Subarea, lake or stream, than the daily quota set out in column IV of that item.

Subsection.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a day, in any Subarea, lake or stream, more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: four hatchery chinook salmon and wild chinook salmon, in the aggregate, that measure 50 cm or less in overall length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two hatchery chinook salmon and wild chinook salmon, in the aggregate, that measure more than 50 cm in overall length;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: four hatchery chinook salmon and wild chinook salmon, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: four hatchery coho salmon and wild coho salmon, in the aggregate, that measure 35 m or less in overall length;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: two hatchery coho salmon and wild coho salmon, in the aggregate, that measure more than 35 m in overall length; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: four hatchery coho salmon and wild coho salmon, in the aggregate.

Subsection.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a day more than four salmon, in the aggregate, from all waters.

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a month in any lake or stream, more than 10 chinook salmon, in the aggregate, that measure more than 50 cm in overall length.
No person shall catch and retain in a year more than:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 20 chinook salmon, in the aggregate, from the waters of Subareas 19-1 to 19-4 and 20-5 to 20-7;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 15 chinook salmon, in the aggregate, from the waters of Area 12 (not including Subarea 12-14), Areas 13 to 18, Area 19 (not including Subareas 19-1 to 19-4), Area 28 and Area 29 (not including the tidal portion of the Fraser River);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 10 chinook salmon that measure more than 50 cm in overall length from the tidal portion of the Fraser River;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: 30 chinook salmon, in the aggregate, from all tidal waters, not including chinook salmon that measure 50 cm or less in overall length that are taken from the tidal portion of the Fraser River; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: 10 chinook salmon that measure more than 50 cm in overall length from all non-tidal waters.

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain a salmon of a species set out in column I of Schedule VI, in any Subarea, lake or stream, the overall length of which is less than the minimum overall length set out in column II.

No person shall fish for salmon by a method or with a type of gear or bait set out in column I of an item of the table to this section in any Subarea, lake or stream during the close time set out in column II of that item.

table.title: Close Times for Salmon Angling by Method, Gear and Bait

row.entry: From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
A hook having more than one point
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
A hook having a single point greater than 15 mm from point to shank
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
Dead fin fish other than roe
Live fin fish other than roe
A hook or an artificial lure
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31

Section.Text: No person shall fish for salmon other than by angling.

Heading.Label: PART V
Heading.TitleText: Fishing for Fin Fish Other than Salmon in Non-Tidal Waters

Section.Text: This Part applies to fishing for fin fish, other than salmon, in non-tidal waters.
Subject to section 53, no person shall fish other than by angling or with a set line.
A person may fish with a spear for burbot or fish of any species not listed in the table to section 58 in Regions 3, 5, 6, 7 and 8.
A person who is fishing with a set line shall not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: use more than one set line;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use a hook that is less than 3 cm measured from the point to the shank; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: retain fish of any species listed in the table to section 58 other than burbot.

Subsection.Text: No person shall fish for, or catch and retain, fish of any species, in a lake or stream, from 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31.
The close time established by subsection (1) is considered to be fixed separately and individually for each species of fish.
No person shall catch and retain in a day more fish of a species set out in column I of Schedule VII, of an overall length set out in column II, than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the daily quota set out in column III or the daily catch limit under section 7 of the Yukon Territory Fishery Regulations, in respect of fish caught in Atlin Lake, Bennett Lake, Laidlaw Lake, Morley Lake, Tagish Lake, Teslin Lake, or in Rancheria River, Swift River or their tributaries; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the daily quota set out in column III, in any other case.

Subsection.Text: A person who, in a day, has caught and retained the daily quota for steelhead in a lake or stream shall cease fishing in that lake or stream for the rest of the day.

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a day from any lake or stream, more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: six wild rainbow trout and hatchery rainbow trout, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one wild steelhead and hatchery steelhead, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: six wild cutthroat trout and hatchery cutthroat trout, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: six wild brown trout and hatchery brown trout, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: six wild brook trout and hatchery brook trout, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: six wild Dolly Varden and hatchery Dolly Varden, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: six wild lake trout and hatchery lake trout, in the aggregate;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: four smallmouth and largemouth bass, in the aggregate; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: 25 wild kokanee and hatchery kokanee, in the aggregate.

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain in a day a quantity of fish of a species set out in column I of an item of the table to this section, from all non-tidal waters, that exceeds the aggregate daily quota set out in column II of that item.
No person shall catch and retain in a month more than two steelhead in any lake or stream.
No person shall catch and retain in a year more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 10 steelhead;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one white sturgeon;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: five rainbow trout greater than 50 cm in overall length from the part of Kootenay Lake east of a line between signs posted at Balfour Point and Proctor Lighthouse;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: five rainbow trout greater than 50 cm in overall length from Shuswap Lake, including Seymour Arm, Anstey Arm and Salmon Arm, Little Shuswap Lake, and the portion of South Thompson River (Little River) between those lakes and Mara Lake; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: five Dolly Varden and lake trout greater than 60 cm in overall length, in the aggregate, from Shuswap Lake, including Seymour Arm, Anstey Arm and Salmon Arm, Little Shuswap Lake, and the portion of South Thompson River (Little River) between those lakes and Mara Lake.

Section.Text: No person shall use as bait or possess for that purpose any freshwater invertebrate at a lake.
Subject to these Regulations, no person shall deposit any substance into the water for the purpose of attracting fish.

No person shall fish for any species of fish by a method or with a type of gear or bait set out in column I of an item of the table to this section, in a lake or stream, during the close time set out in column II of that item.

table.title: Close Times for Fishing by Method, Gear and Bait

row.entry: From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
A hook having more than one point
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
A hook having a single point greater than 15 mm from point to shank
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31
Dead fin fish other than roe
Live fin fish other than roe
A hook or an artificial lure
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on Dec. 31

Section.Text: The contravention of a provision of these Regulations set out in column I of an item of Schedule VIII is an offence to which section 79.7 of the Act applies and may be described in tickets in the manner set out in column II of that item.

Where proceedings are commenced under section 79.7 of the Act, the amount of the fine for an offence described in column II of an item of Schedule VIII is the amount set out in column III of that item.

row.entry: Charlotte unarmored stickleback, Enos stickleback or giant stickleback

Provision.Text: Any species of Decapoda except Cancer magister and Cancer productus

row.entry: Any species of Hexagrammidae except Ophiodon elongatus
Any species of Archaeogastropoda except Haliotis kamtschatkana
Any species of Pleuronectidae except Hippoglossus stenolepis

table.title: Waters in Which the Use of a Vessel Equipped with a Motor Is Prohibited While Angling

row.entry: Chilko River above bridge at Henry’s Crossing
Horsefly River, from Woodjam Bridge to Quesnel Lake

table.title: Waters in Which the Use of a Vessel Is Prohibited While Angling

row.entry: Babine River below fish counting fence
Bulkley River from Morice River to C.N. bridge at Barrett
Bulkley River in Moricetown Canyon and within 100 m below Moricetown Canyon
Skeena River within a triangular area bounded by three fishing boundary signs posted at the mouth of Kispiox River

table.title: Gear, Close Times and Quotas for Fin Fish Other than Salmon in Tidal Waters

Provision.Text: From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31
From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31

From 23:00 hrs to 24:00 hrs on December 31
